ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basic techniques of fresco, egg tempera, and oil. A material and theoretical investigation of painting across time, place, and medium.
materials knowledge in fresco and egg tempera, practice producing things for a studio course

I learned patience and courage with my composition and choices. I learned how to paint with oils and how to make gesso and prime a canvas. I learned how to fresco and make pigments and egg tempura paint.
My artistic abilities in both an intellectual and mechanical way. Insight into my own thought process in my work and the works of others.
Learned new techniques like fresco painting and egg tempera, developed my style as an artist more

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great readings, demos, lectures, and critiques. Very good environment. Could be better if there was more oil painting in class.

A wonderful course. The only thing I wish is that our final review was at the end of finals and not during reading week. It would just give more time to work on the art and develop that last week. Otherwise, I don't think I'd change a thing.

course largely depends on who's teaching it, I think it should be 1x per week for 3 hours though so you can actually get things done in class. 1hr 50 min 2x a week is a lot of course time and doesn't allow for that much to get done in each class period.
We spent a bit more time doing the demos (for frescos or tempura) and then wouldnt have enough time to follow the instructions and make our materials.
Very well taught and good pacing of the work. No weaknesses.

Strengths: knowledge and passion of professor, good peer group, lots of freedom
Weaknesses: not much feedback, readings sometimes felt unrelated/very dense without much context

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Phenomenal class to investigate content and develop ones visual language and artistic practice

Absolutely. Oscar is a fantastic teacher and approaches the material and technical aspects of painting in a very smart and theoretically grounded way. We began with fresco, then did egg tempera, then continued on to oil and he knows each medium very well (especially fresco).

this class is really what you make of it -- you can produce small pieces and do them last minute or you can lean in and work really hard. Crits are more generative than critical. Course depends a lot on who's teaching; Oscar is great and emphasizes learning materials (fresco, egg tempera) and pairing with more theoretical readings. We didn't do much painting in class which means that the time per week for the class is kind of a lot because class itself is 4 hours per week, and then you add outside painting on that. First half of the class has painting prompts and the second is very open ended.
Yes, it was a meditative class that took one out of the university mindset and got me thinking about broader concepts outside my own experience
absolutely. take it with oscar hes an incredible professor and artist. I loved this course.

I would recommend the course to someone who wants to expand/keep up their painting practice at Yale if they are comfortable with a very open-ended format. You can pretty much do anything you want, which is exciting but intimidating also. It was very self-drivenbesides Oscar's tutorials on new techniques, most of the course was independent studio time.
